prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO 3-2 in Q01322-0051
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Goal is to measure spatially resolved CO (3-2) map of a z~0.1 galaxy. Baseband 1 is set to measure the CO (3-2) spectral line and the remaining 3 basebands measure continuum. The line flux surface density goal is estimated from Cycle 1 CO(1-0) flux and diameter, and typical 3-2/1-0 ratios. It represents a surface density in the outskirts assuming a centrally peaked disk, rather than a uniform average surface density.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
These 6 galaxies were selected from IRAS + SDSS to have L_IR > 1e11.5, large optical diameter, disky morphology, and star-forming spectrum. We obtained Herschel PACS spectra of the [C II], [O I], [O III], and [N II] far-IR lines. MMT long-slit optical spectra of H-alpha measure the star-forming diameter. In ALMA cycle 1 we observed the galaxies in CO(1-0). We predict S_CO(3-2) from the CO(1-0) flux and the excitation ratio r_31, which we aim to measure. A typical to low excitation ratio is r_31 = T(3-2) / T(1-0) ~ 0.5 in antenna temperature, or 4.5 in flux units (e.g. Yao et al 2003, Papadopoulos et al 2011).
Our CO(1-0) observations reached an rms of 0.6-0.7 mJy/beam per 20 km/s channel, and detected the CO disk to ~0.1 Jy km/s surface brightness at about 5 sigma. For a ratio of the CO lines, r_31 = 4.5 in flux units, this corresponds to an rms of 2.9 mJy/beam. To measure the line ratio to the outskirts of the disk, we require to reach a sensitivity 2x fainter, 1.5 mJy/beam in 20 km/s bandwidth. This means we will still detect gas in CO(3-2) in an area of the disk where r_31 is 0.25 in temperature or 2.25 in flux units, an unusually low value.
The 20 km/s bandwidth is well matched to galaxy kinematics and resolves the disk velocity width, which is broadened by beam smearing.
The total CO(1-0) fluxes of the galaxies are typically ~20 Jy km/s and diameter 8", predicting a total CO(3-2) flux of ~90 Jy km/s.
The continuum sensitivity, combining the basebands, is typically <0.1 mJy/beam. For a typical galaxy with S_100 um = 1.5 Jy, and a Draine \& Li (2007) dust model, the expected total continuum flux at 0.9mm is 10 mJy, yielding a strong detection of the total flux and a spatially resolved radial profile with averaging in annuli. These can be used with the IR fluxes to constrain the cool dust in dust mass modeling.

We are requesting spectral averaging by 8x in baseband 1 for a channel width of 3.7 km/s. The narrowest velocity width likely to be seen is 10-12 km/s and 20-30 km/s is more probable, since each beam averages over part of the galaxy disk. So the averaged channels will comfortably resolve the emission in velocity.

We request an angular resolution of 1.0", which is 1.5-2 kpc for these galaxies, and is well matched to the 1.0-1.2" beamwidth of our Cycle 1 CO(1-0) observations. This angular resolution gives 5-10 resolution elements across the major axis of each object. It will resolve velocity gradients and spatially resolve the ratio of the 3-2 / 1-0 lines. The largest angular scale requested is the diameter of detected CO(1-0) flux in Cycle 1 observations.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose CO(3-2) observations of 6 z ~ 0.1 IR-luminous galaxies that are large gas-rich disks, unlike most low-z LIRG/ULIRGs which are centrally concentrated mergers. We mapped these 6 galaxies in CO(1-0) in Cycle 1, selected from a sample of 16 disky U/LIRGs that we observed in [C II] 158 microns and other far-IR lines with Herschel. They have large H_2 gas masses 0.6-10e10 Msolar. At high-z, many star-forming galaxies are disky with high gas fraction, with star formation spread over a large area. Our sample are analogs for these high-z disks, yet can be studied in more detail. [C II] 158 um and other far-IR lines probe the density and UV ionization in star-forming regions. CO(3-2) maps will probe higher density gas than CO(1-0), and measure the spatially resolved CO line excitation ratio, sensitive to temperature and gas density. We will test the excitation dependence on radius, local gas and SFR surface density, SF efficiency L_IR / M_H_2, T_dust, and galaxy type (disks vs. mergers). We will test models in which the CO excitation is set by SFR surface density, and calibrate the CO 3-2/1-0 ratio for interpreting high-J CO fluxes of high-z galaxies and converting to CO(1-0).
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00539.S - Molecular gas and starforming regions in disky U/LIRGs - analogs for high-z starforming galaxies - PI Benjamin Weiner , 2013.1.00954.S
prp:ObsProposal.prp:keyword: Luminous and Ultra-Luminous Infra-Red Galaxies (LIRG & ULIRG)
